title-group.article-title: Measuring the Effective Tax Burden in the Real World

abstract.p: This paper argues that forward-looking indices of the effective tax burden on income from capital – namely, effective marginal and average tax rates – are negatively biased because traditional models overlook dividend constraints associated with financial tax incentives, such as accelerated depreciation. The paper presents measures of the two indices adjusted to remove the bias and compares the new indices with the traditional ones. Numerical simulations carried out to quantify the magnitude of the bias for France, Germany, Ireland, Italy and the UK give evidence of sizeable distortions in the unadjusted indices and, in turn, suggest significant mismeasurement in the current assessment of the effective tax burden.

EMTRs and EATRs are widely used indices of the effective tax burden in studies on the impact of capital income taxation on investment choices. See, for example, OECD (1991), PriceWaterhouseCoopers (1998), Baker & McKenzie (1999), Bond and Chennells (2000), European Commission (2001a and 2001b) and Finkenzeller and Spengel (2004).
For a detailed assessment of the advantages and disadvantages of measuring the effective tax burden through EMTRs and EATRs, see European Commission (2001a).

A permanent difference between the tax and accounting assessments occurs whenever an item of revenue or cost is solely assessed for accounting or tax purposes. Examples include tax-free revenues (gains benefiting from a special exemption regime) or expenditures expressly disallowed for tax purposes (such as business entertainment) and expenses for items not entirely related to the business (such as mobile phones and cars).
Rules for recording timing differences in a company's financial statement vary within the EU countries. For a detailed outline, see Alexander and Archer (2003).

For further reading on the links between IAS/IFRS and tax rules, see Schön (2004). For a more detailed assessment of the connections between tax and commercial reporting systems, see the introductory sections in Haverals (2005) and Lamb, Nobes and Roberts (1998).
